TEXT.English: [TAB]Originally several separate territories under the control of the Holy Roman Empire, and then united into one state under Habsburg rule (16th century), the Netherlands did not acquire national independence until the conclusion of the Eighty Years' War (1568-1648 AD) when the Spanish formally renounced all claims to Dutch sovereignty in the Treaty of Mьnster.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Eighty Years' War was sparked by Spanish religious oppression and an occupation by Spanish forces led by the Duke of Alba, during which over one thousand people were sentenced to death, including two prominent and popular Dutch nobles; these actions caused dissention among the Dutch people. In 1568 Willem, Prince of Orange, returned from a self-imposed exile (in order to avoid prosecution by the Duke of Alba) and led the uprising against the Spanish occupation.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Dutch fight for independence can be seen as a war against religious oppression, with the Pacification of Ghent treaty being a written representation of this sentiment. Signed on November 8th, 1576 the document specified an alliance between the Dutch provinces, in which religious differences would be put aside for the purposes of expelling the Spanish and restoring local provincial control to the Netherlands.[PARAGRAPH:2]During the seventeenth century the Dutch began using their large military and merchant navies to both create their own trading posts along the African coast and rob those of the Portuguese in an effort to reach valuable markets in India and Indonesia. The inrush of treasure, trade and knowledge from these trading and military expeditions was extremely beneficial, and during this first half of the seventeenth century the Dutch experienced a Golden Age of cultural and economic growth. This Golden Age would soon come to a crushing end.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1795, France, under Napoleon I, conquered the Dutch mainland. The Netherlands quickly declined in influence and power, locally and internationally, with the British taking most of their colonial possessions. After Napoleon was defeated a few colonial territories were restored to the Dutch and remained under their control until the decolonization of the twentieth century.[PARAGRAPH:2]Many historians regard the Dutch empire as the first truly capitalist country. In addition to developing the first stock exchange, many modern services such as corporate insurance and retirement funds were attributed to Dutch inventiveness.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Netherlands is also the birthplace of one of the world's early democratic institutions - the Dutch Water Boards. Due to the unique topography of the Netherlands - about half of the mainland is a foot or more under sea level - the country's waterways must be constantly monitored and controlled in order to prevent flooding that would result in tremendous loss of life and property. Each Water Board is in charge of one of the nation's 27 water districts and all matters pertaining to local water management. The creation of these water boards predates the Netherlands itself. [PARAGRAPH:2]The modern Netherlands, with a diverse population and liberal laws towards drugs, prostitution, abortion, same-sex marriage, and euthanasia, has been a constant haven for refugees from other countries. Cultural minorities are encouraged to protect their own cultural identity while at the same time integrate into Dutch culture at large, further reinforcing the open-minded ideals for which Dutch ancestors fought and died.
TEXT.French: A l'origine, les Pays-Bas йtaient constituйs de plusieurs territoires, d'abord sйparйs sous le contrфle du Saint Empire romain germanique, puis unifiйs sous le rиgne des Habsbourg (16иme siиcle). Les Pays-Bas n'acquiиrent leur indйpendance qu'а la fin de la Guerre de quatre-vingts ans (1568-1648) quand les Espagnols renoncent officiellement а toute prйtention sur la souverainetй nйerlandaise en signant le Traitй de Mьnster.[PARAGRAPH:1]La Guerre de quatre-vingts ans est dйclenchйe par l'oppression religieuse Espagnole et par l'occupation des troupes hispaniques (menйes par le duc d'Albe), au cours de laquelle plus de mille personnes sont condamnйes а mort, y compris deux membres importants de la noblesse nйerlandaise, provoquant le soulиvement du peuple nйerlandais. En 1568, Guillaume, prince d'Orange, revient d'un exil qu'il s'йtait lui-mкme imposй (afin d'йviter d'кtre poursuivi par le duc d'Albe) et mиne la rйvolte contre l'occupation espagnole.[PARAGRAPH:1] La lutte nйerlandaise pour l'indйpendance peut кtre considйrйe comme une guerre contre le sentiment d'oppression religieuse, sentiment dont le traitй de Pacification de Gand sera la reprйsentation йcrite. Ce document, signй le 8 novembre 1576, consacre une alliance entre les provinces nйerlandaises, au sein de laquelle les diffйrents religieux seront mis de cфtй afin de chasser les espagnols et de restaurer un contrфle local sur les Pays-Bas.[PARAGRAPH:1]Au cours du 17иme siиcle, les nйerlandais commencent а utiliser leurs vastes marines militaires et marchandes pour crйer leurs propres postes de commerce le long de la cфte Africaine et piller les comptoirs portugais, afin d'atteindre les prйcieux marchйs d'Inde et d'Indonйsie. Les revenus financiers, commerciaux et scientifiques de ces expйditions commerciales et militaires sont extrкmement substantiels et, durant la premiиre moitiй du dix-septiиme siиcle, les nйerlandais connaissent un вge d'or provoquй par une forte croissance йconomique et culturelle. Cet вge d'or doit bientфt s'achever dans le sang.[PARAGRAPH:1]En 1795 la France, sous Napolйon Ier, conquiert les Pays-Bas continentaux. Les Pays-Bas perdent rapidement pouvoir et influence, localement et mondialement, tandis que les Anglais s'emparent de leurs possessions coloniales. Aprиs la dйfaite de Napolйon, quelques colonies sont rendues aux Nйerlandais et demeurent sous leur contrфle jusqu'а la dйcolonisation du vingtiиme siиcle.[PARAGRAPH:1]De nombreux historiens considиrent l'empire nйerlandais comme le premier pays rйellement capitaliste. En plus de la premiиre Bourse, de nombreux services modernes comme les assurances et les fonds de retraite sont attribuйs а l'innovation nйerlandaise.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les Pays-bas sont aussi la patrie de l'une des premiиres institutions dйmocratiques mondiales : les Conseils de l'eau nйerlandais. En raison de la topographie unique des Pays-Bas (environ la moitiй du continent est situйe trente centimиtres ou plus au-dessous du niveau de la mer), les voies navigables doivent кtre constamment surveillйes et contrфlйes afin d'йviter une inondation qui provoquerait des pertes humaines et matйrielles considйrables. Chaque Conseil de l'eau est responsable de l'une des 27 agences de l'eau de la nation et de toutes les affaires relatives а la gestion de l'eau. La crйation de ces Conseils de l'eau prйcиde celle des Pays-bas eux-mкmes. [PARAGRAPH:1]Avec une population trиs diversifiйe et des lois libйrales concernant les drogues, la prostitution, l'avortement, le mariage homosexuel et l'euthanasie, les Pays-Bas modernes sont toujours une destination de prйdilection pour les rйfugiйs. Le gouvernement nйerlandais encourage les minoritйs а protйger leur propre identitй culturelle tout en intйgrant la culture nйerlandaise dans son ensemble, renforзant ainsi davantage les idйaux d'ouverture pour lesquels les ancкtres nйerlandais se sont battus jusqu'а la mort.

TEXT.Italian: Inizialmente i Paesi Bassi erano territori separati sotto il controllo del Sacro Romano Impero e vennero uniti in un unico stato sotto la guida degli Asburgo (XIV secolo) ma non acquisirono una propria indipendenza fino alla fine della Guerra degli 80 anni (1568-1648 d.C.), quando la Spagna rinunciт formalmente a tutte le pretese sulla sovranitа olandese, con il Trattato di Mьnster.[PARAGRAPH:1]La Guerra degli 80 anni fu scatenata dall'oppressione religiosa da parte degli spagnoli e dall'occupazione di forze iberiche guidate dal Duca d'Alba, durante la quale mille persone furono condannate a morte, tra cui due nobili olandesi prominenti e popolari; queste azioni causarono il dissenso della popolazione olandese. Nel 1568 Guglielmo, principe d'Orange, tornт da un esilio autoimposto (per evitare la persecuzione del Duca d'Alba) e guidт la rivolta contro l'occupazione spagnola.[PARAGRAPH:1]La lotta olandese per l'indipendenza puт essere vista come una guerra contro l'oppressione religiosa e la Pacificazione di Gand la rappresentazione scritta di tale sentimento. Firmato l'8 novembre del 1576, questo documento stabiliva un'alleanza tra le province olandesi in cui le differenze religiose venivano messe da parte per cercare di cacciare gli spagnoli e di ripristinare il controllo provinciale locale dei Paesi Bassi.[PARAGRAPH:1]Durante il diciassettesimo secolo gli olandesi cominciarono a utilizzare la propria marina mercantile e militare sia per creare delle stazioni commerciali lungo le coste africane sia per derubare quelle portoghesi, nel tentativo di raggiungere i preziosi mercati in India e Indonesia. L'afflusso di tesori, commercio e conoscenza derivanti da queste spedizioni militari e commerciali ebbe un effetto estremamente positivo e, durante la prima metа del diciassettesimo secolo, gli olandesi conobbero un periodo di grande crescita culturale ed economica. Un'etа dell'oro che sarebbe presto tragicamente terminata.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nel 1795 la Francia, sotto Napoleone I, conquistт l'Olanda. I Paesi Bassi persero rapidamente influenza e potere, sia a livello locale sia internazionale, e i britannici presero la maggior parte dei loro possedimenti coloniali. Dopo la sconfitta di Napoleone alcuni territori coloniali tornarono agli olandesi e rimasero sotto il loro controllo fino alla decolonizzazione del ventesimo secolo.[PARAGRAPH:1]Molti storici vedono l'impero olandese come il primo paese realmente capitalista. Oltre ad aver sviluppato la prima borsa azionaria, molti altri servizi moderni come le assicurazioni aziendali e i fondi di pensionamento sono da imputare all'inventivitа olandese.[PARAGRAPH:1]I Paesi Bassi sono anche il luogo di nascita di una delle prime istituzioni democratiche al mondo: i Distretti di Controllo delle Acque (Water Boards). A causa dell'insolita topografia del Paese, circa una metа dei Paesi Bassi и di una trentina di centimetri al di sotto del livello del mare: i corsi d'acqua devono essere costantemente controllati per prevenire allagamenti che causerebbero perdite di vite e di proprietа. Ogni distretto si occupa di una delle 27 aree in cui и diviso il Paese e di tutti i problemi inerenti alla gestione locale delle acque. La creazione di tali distretti и antecedente a quella degli stessi Paesi Bassi. [PARAGRAPH:1]I moderni Paesi Bassi, con una popolazione eterogenea e leggi liberali su droga, prostituzione, aborto, matrimoni tra persone dello stesso sesso ed eutanasia accolgono da sempre rifugiati da altri Paesi. Le minoranze culturali sono incoraggiate a difendere la propria identitа culturale, pur integrandosi ampiamente nella cultura olandese, rinforzando in questo modo gli ideali di larghe vedute per cui gli antenati olandesi combatterono e morirono.
TEXT.Spanish: Holanda, que originariamente solo era varios territorios separados bajo el control del Sacro Imperio Romano y mбs tarde unificados en un solo estado bajo el dominio de los Habsburgo (siglo XVI), no alcanzу la independencia hasta el final de la Guerra de los Ochenta Aсos (1568-1648), cuando, en el tratado de Mьnster, los espaсoles renunciaron finalmente a sus pretensiones de soberanнa sobre ella.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lo que desencadenу la Guerra de los Ochenta Aсos fue la intolerancia religiosa de los espaсoles y la ocupaciуn del paнs por parte de las fuerzas del duque de Alba, que sentenciу a muerte a un millar de personas, incluidos dos importantes y populares nobles. En 1568, Guillermo, prнncipe de Orange, regresу del exilio que йl mismo se habнa impuesto (para no caer en manos del Duque de Alba) y se puso a la cabeza de la revuelta.[PARAGRAPH:1]La lucha por la independencia de los holandeses puede verse como una guerra contra la opresiуn religiosa, sentimiento encarnado en la llamada Pacificaciуn de Gante. Firmado el 8 de noviembre de 1576, este documento establecнa una alianza entre las diferentes provincias holandesas, cuyas diferencias religiosas serнan apartadas con el fin de expulsar a los espaсoles y recuperar la autonomнa.[PARAGRAPH:1]A lo largo del siglo XVII, los holandeses empezaron a utilizar sus grandes barcos mercantes y de guerra para establecer puestos comerciales a lo largo de la costa africana y asaltar los de los portugueses, en un intento por alcanzar los ricos mercados de la India e Indonesia. La llegada de riquezas, mercancнas y conocimientos generado por estas expediciones comerciales y militares fue extremadamente beneficio y, durante la primera mitad del siglo XVII, los holandeses vivieron una edad dorada de crecimiento cultural y econуmico. Esta edad de oro no tardarнa en sufrir un fin dolorosamente brusco.[PARAGRAPH:1]En 1795, los ejйrcitos franceses de Napoleуn I conquistaron la metrуpolis holandesa. Holanda experimentу un acusado declive en su influencia y poder, tanto local como internacionalmente, y los britбnicos se apoderaron de la mayor parte de sus colonias. Tras la derrota de Napoleуn, algunos de los territorios coloniales fueron devueltos a los holandeses, y permanecieron bajo su control hasta el proceso descolonizador del siglo XX.[PARAGRAPH:1]Muchos historiadores consideran al imperio holandйs el primer estado realmente capitalista. Ademбs de desarrollar la primera bolsa de la historia, muchas instituciones modernas, como los seguros corporativos y los fondos de pensiones, se consideran inventos holandeses.[PARAGRAPH:1]Holanda fue tambiйn el escenario de la apariciуn de una de las primeras instituciones democrбticas del mundo: las Juntas del agua. Debido a las especiales caracterнsticas topogrбficas de Holanda (casi la mitad del paнs estб mбs de treinta centнmetros por debajo del nivel del mar), los rнos deben ser objeto de vigilancia y control constantes para prevenir inundaciones y pйrdidas catastrуficas. Cada Junta del agua controla uno de los 27 distritos hidrogrбficos del paнs, y gestiona todo lo referente a los recursos hнdricos. La creaciуn de estas instituciones es anterior al nacimiento del propio estado de Holanda. [PARAGRAPH:1]La moderna Holanda, con su poblaciуn cosmopolita y su legislaciуn liberal con respecto a las drogas, la prostituciуn, el aborto, los matrimonios homosexuales y la eutanasia, ha sido un autйntico paraнso para refugiados procedentes de otras regiones. Se alienta a las minorнas a proteger su identidad cultural, al tiempo que se integran en la cultura holandesa en su conjunto, lo que contribuye a reforzar los ideales de tolerancia por los que lucharon y murieron los antepasados de los holandeses.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Mayan Empire blossomed within the thick jungles and volcanic hills of Belize, Guatemala and the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico. Creators of the most advanced civilization in the Americas from 700 BC until 900 AD, the Mayan population in its age was second only to the Chinese T'ang dynasty in sheer numbers.[PARAGRAPH:2]Often referred to as the "Greeks of the New World," the Mayans were similarly organized into a series of feuding city states, although these cities served more religious and administrative purposes than as populations centers. Uniting the Maya culture was a common language, religion and artistic style, but each city state remained fiercely independent, often uniting only at the point of a Holkan spear. [PARAGRAPH:2]Every city-state was governed by its own royal family, whom often claimed full or semi-divinity. During the Mayan Classical Period from roughly 250 to 900 AD, these cities became vast complexes of pyramids, causeways and plazas. Nakbe, the first city-state to grow on a grand scale, began its expansion around 700 BC. By 300 BC, Nakbe had been transformed into an impressive city, with four grand step pyramids and a seven mile stone causeway linking it to the nearby city of El Mirador. [PARAGRAPH:2]Nakbe was only the first of many vast cities. Chichen Itza, Tikal and Palenque all became massive population centers. With myriad pyramids and religious structures, Tikal grew to become a city of the grandest scale and the largest of the Mayan population centers, dwarfing Palenque and Copan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Palenque, a significantly smaller settlement to the West, reached its zenith in the seventh century AD under the reign of Pacal II, whose subjugation of neighboring cities ensured the hegemony of his own. Much is known about Pacal and his city thanks to the intricately-carved history left to us within Pacal's tomb, "The Temple of Inscriptions," entire walls of which were filled with the Mayans' distinctive pictographic language, the only written language developed in the Americas. [PARAGRAPH:2]Language was not the only realm in which Mayan minds excelled. Their calendars were nearly on par with those of the modern era, but were created without the use of the telescope or other tools. Independent development of the number zero, an accomplishment that eluded both the Greeks and Romans, was yet another of the impressive feats of the Mayans. [PARAGRAPH:2]Most of these discoveries grew out of the Mayan religion. And while certainly interested in knowledge, the Mayan religion was ensconced in the belief of the power of blood. Many wars among the Maya were fought simply to provide prisoners to be sacrificed in intricate religious ceremonies, thought necessary to ensure the safety and advancement of the people. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Mayan civilization came to a surprisingly abrupt end, and the cause of this fall is still a hotly debated topic. One of the most widely-accepted theories is that the delicate ecology of the Yucatan rainforests simply could no longer support the growing population of the Mayan people. A peasant revolt is also a likely cause of the fall of Mayan priestly caste, as belief in brutal Mayan rituals fell to the wayside. [PARAGRAPH:2]But the popular notion that the Mayans simply disappeared is false. While the grand temple building, intricate carvings and sacrifices ceased, the Mayan language and people continued to survive in their former homeland, even after the conquest of their country by Spanish conquistadors. The Mayan languages, Yucatec being the most common, are still spoken to this day and armed resistance by the Maya continued into the twentieth century. The Maya remain a living people.
TEXT.French: L'empire maya prospиre au milieu des jungles йpaisses et des collines volcaniques du Belize, du Guatemala et de la pйninsule mexicaine du Yucatan. Fondateurs de la civilisation la plus avancйe des Amйriques entre 700 av. J.C. et 900 ap. J.C, les Mayas forment а cette йpoque la deuxiиme plus grande population du monde, juste aprиs la dynastie chinoise des T'ang.[PARAGRAPH:1]Souvent surnommйs les "grecs du nouveau monde", les Mayas sont eux aussi organisйs en citйs guerriиres, mкme si ces citйs servent plus de centres religieux et administratifs que de centres populaires. Les Mayas sont liйs par une langue, une religion et un style artistique communs, mais chaque citй demeure fйrocement indйpendante, ne s'unissant souvent qu'au bout de la lance d'un holkan. [PARAGRAPH:1]Chaque citй est gouvernйe par sa propre famille royale, qui se rйclame souvent d'origine divine ou semi-divine. Au cours de l'иre classique maya, de 250 а 900 ap. J.C. environ, ces citйs deviennent de vastes complexes abritant nombre de pyramides, de chaussйes et de places. Nakbe, la premiиre citй а connaоtre un dйveloppement de grande ampleur, entame son expansion aux environs de 700 av. J.C. En 300 av. J.C. Nakbe se transforme en une immense ville, pourvue de quatre grandes pyramides et d'une chaussйe en pierre de onze kilomиtres reliant la ville а la citй voisine de El Mirador.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mais d'autres villes connaissent la mкme croissance. Chichйn Itzб, Tikal et Palenque deviennent toutes d'immenses centres urbains. Dotйe d'une myriade de pyramides et de structures religieuses, Tikal devient une ville grandiose et le plus grand centre de population maya, йclipsant mкme Palenque et Copan.[PARAGRAPH:1]Palenque, petite colonie de l'ouest, atteint son zйnith au septiиme siиcle avant J.C. sous le rиgne de Pacal II qui, en assujettissant les citйs voisines, assure l'hйgйmonie de la sienne. Nous savons beaucoup de choses sur Pacal et sa ville grвce au Temple des inscriptions, dont les murs sont couverts de symboles mayas, lesquels formaient le seul langage йcrit dйveloppй dans les Amйriques.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les mayas n'ont pas excellй que pour le langage. Leurs calendriers йtaient presque aussi sophistiquйs que ceux de l'иre moderne alors qu'ils ne disposaient ni du tйlescope ni d'aucun autre outil. L'invention du chiffre zйro, qui avait йchappй aux Grecs et aux Romains, est йgalement а mettre sur le compte de l'ingйniositй maya. [PARAGRAPH:1]La plupart de ces dйcouvertes trouvent leur origine dans la religion maya. Mкme si elle s'intйresse aux nouvelles connaissances, cette derniиre croit fortement au pouvoir du sang. De nombreuses guerres sont menйes dans le simple but de fournir des prisonniers а sacrifier lors de cйrйmonies religieuses trиs complexes, que les Mayas considиrent nйcessaires а la sйcuritй et au dйveloppement de leur peuple.[PARAGRAPH:1]La civilisation maya connaоt une fin йtrangement brusque, dont la cause est encore l'objet de nombreux dйbats. L'une des thйories les plus rйpandues est que le fragile йcosystиme des forкts du Yucatan ne pouvait plus soutenir la croissance de la population. Une rйvolte de paysans pourrait йgalement кtre а l'origine du dйclin de la caste des prкtres, au moment mкme oщ la croyance en leurs rites brutaux ne rassemblait plus autant d'adeptes. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mais il serait faut de penser que les Mayas ont disparu. Certes, la construction de temples et la pratique de sacrifices ont cessй, mais la langue et le peuple mayas ont continuй а survivre, mкme aprиs les conquкtes des conquistadors. Les langues mayas (parmi lesquelles la plus courante est le maya yucatиque) sont encore parlйes de nos jours et la rйsistance armйe maya se poursuivit jusqu'au vingtiиme siиcle. TEXT.Italian: L'impero maya fiorм nelle fitte giungle e sulle colline vulcaniche di Belize, Guatemala e sulla penisola dello Yucatan in Messico. La popolazione maya rappresentт la civiltа piщ avanzata in America dal 700 a.C. fino al 900 d.C. e, a suo tempo, fu inferiore come numero solo a quella cinese della dinastia T'ang.[PARAGRAPH:1]Spesso definiti i "Greci del Nuovo Mondo", i Maya erano analogamente organizzati in una serie di cittа-stato in lotta tra loro, anche se tali cittа avevano scopi piщ religiosi e amministrativi che non fungere da centri della popolazione. A unire la cultura maya erano linguaggio, religione e stile artistico comuni, ma ogni cittа-stato rimaneva fieramente indipendente, spesso unita solo grazie alla punta della lancia di un Holkan. [PARAGRAPH:1]Ogni cittа-stato era governata dalla propria famiglia reale, che spesso rivendicava una divinitа parziale o totale. Durante il periodo classico maya, all'incirca dal 250 al 900 d.C., queste cittа divennero vasti complessi di piramidi, sentieri rialzati e piazze. Nakbe fu la prima cittа-stato a crescere molto e cominciт la propria espansione attorno al 700 a.C. Nel 300 a.C. Nakbe si era trasformata in una cittа impressionante, con quattro piramidi a gradoni e un sentiero in pietra di quasi dodici chilometri che la collegava alla vicina cittа di El Mirador. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nakbe fu solo la prima di molte cittа immense. Chichen Itza, Tikal e Palenque divennero tutte grossi centri urbani. Con miriadi di piramidi e strutture religiose, Tikal crebbe fino a diventare la cittа piщ importante e il maggiore fra i centri popolati dei Maya, ancor piщ di Palenque e Copan.[PARAGRAPH:1]Palenque, un insediamento decisamente piщ piccolo a ovest, raggiunse il massimo splendore nel settimo secolo d.C. sotto il regno di Pakal II, che sottomise le cittа circostanti assicurando l'egemonia della propria. Molto si sa di Pakal e della sua cittа grazie alla storia incisa all'interno della sua tomba, il "Tempio delle Iscrizioni". Al suo interno, interi muri erano ricoperti con la caratteristica scrittura pittografica dei Maya, l'unico linguaggio scritto mai sviluppato in America. [PARAGRAPH:1]Il linguaggio non era l'unico campo in cui le menti dei Maya eccellevano. I loro calendari sono quasi al livello di quelli odierni ma furono creati senza l'uso di telescopi o altri strumenti. La scoperta indipendente del numero zero, cosa che sfuggм a Greci e Romani, и un'altra delle impressionanti imprese dei Maya. [PARAGRAPH:1]La maggior parte di queste scoperte и da imputare alla religione Maya. E, pur essendo interessati alla conoscenza, la loro religione era basata sulla fede nel potere del sangue. Molte guerre tra i Maya furono combattute semplicemente con lo scopo di ottenere prigionieri da sacrificare in complesse cerimonie religiose, che si pensava fossero necessarie per assicurare la salvezza e il progresso. [PARAGRAPH:1]La civiltа Maya ebbe una fine brusca e prematura e il motivo и ancora fonte di dibattito. Una delle teorie piщ diffuse и che la delicata ecologia delle foreste dello Yucatan non riuscм piщ a sopportare la popolazione in aumento della civiltа maya. Anche la rivolta dei contadini potrebbe essere una causa verosimile della caduta della casta dei preti maya, per via di una diminuzione della fede nei brutali rituali maya. [PARAGRAPH:1]Ma la diffusa credenza che il popolo maya sia veramente scomparso и falsa. Gli enormi templi, i complessi geroglifici e i sacrifici sono terminati, ma la lingua e il popolo maya continuano a sopravvivere nella loro vecchia patria, anche dopo la conquista del loro Paese da parte dei conquistatori spagnoli. Lo Yucatec и il piщ diffuso tra gli idiomi maya, molti dei quali sono parlati ancora oggi, e la resistenza armata dei Maya и continuata fino al ventesimo secolo. I Maya rimangono un popolo vivo.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Ethiopia is believed by many historians to be the birthplace of the human race. Lucy, a 3.2 million year old human skeleton, was discovered in Ethiopia's Afar Depression. However, beyond Lucy, there is little evidence to suggest (one way or another) that Ethiopia was settled until roughly the eighth century BC, when it is theorized that Jewish settlers fleeing Egypt, Sudan, and southern Arabia settled there.[PARAGRAPH:2]The first recorded government in Ethiopia was the Kingdom of Axum in the first century AD. Information on this kingdom is scarce; its founder remains unknown. But under Axum rule, Ethiopia became the first Christian nation in Africa. In roughly 330 AD, Frumentius, a Greek from Tyre, was consecrated the first bishop of Ethiopia by Saint Athanasius. Frumentius spread Christianity in Ethiopia through the construction of churches on land given to him by the Axum emperor. Although Christianity did not become a widespread religion in the region until much later, Frumentius can be considered the originator of Christianity in Ethiopia.[PARAGRAPH:2]Although Ethiopia had traditionally been the target for Muslim raids in the region, it was not until 1528 that a full scale invasion was successful. Under the leadership of Imam Ahmad ibn Ibrihim al-Ghazi, Muslim forces swept through Ethiopia, routing the emperor's forces and sending him into hiding. Unable to re-secure his homeland with Ethiopian forces alone, Emperor Lebna Dengel Dawit II petitioned the Portuguese to assist defeating the invaders. In 1541 the Portuguese deployed an army of 400 musketeers to assist the emperor, and while these forces were defeated at the Battle of Wofla, the Muslims were ultimately forced to retreat when their leader was killed the following year at the Battle of Wayna Daga.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ethiopia had been wracked by a series of internal conflicts throughout the sixteenth and seventeenth century. While not splintering the nation, these conflicts eroded the empire's central power until the feuding families were ultimately defeated by Tewodros II, who ruled Ethiopia between 1855 and 1868. Despite a prestigious military career, Tewodros II committed an egregious political faux pas when, in 1867, he imprisoned several British nationals after Queen Victoria of the England failed to answer a letter he had sent to her. The British swiftly sent an army to rescue the British citizens, and upon the Ethiopian army's defeat, Tewdros II committed suicide.[PARAGRAPH:2]Soon after, in 1870, the Italians, who had bought the Ethiopian costal city of Eritrea from a local Sultan, claimed that the Treaty of Wuchale (1889), an agreement between Italy and Ethiopia on the official boundaries between Ethiopia and Eritera, granted them sovereignty over all of Ethiopia, though in reality it only specified a very small portion of Northern Ethiopia near Eritrea. The Italians sent an army to conquer Ethiopia, but were repelled by Emperor Menelek II at the Battle of Adowa. After their defeat, the Italians signed the Treaty of Addis Ababa (1896) which recognized Ethiopia as an independent state. As it turned out, the Italians would be back.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1936 the Italians once again invaded and occupied Ethiopia, this time under the fascist dictatorship of Mussolini, forcing the emperor to flee to England. The Italians were eventually defeated in 1941 by combined British and Ethiopian forces.[PARAGRAPH:2]Perhaps the most influential Ethiopian Emperor of the modern era was Haile Selassie I. Ruling from 1930 until his death in 1974 (with the exception of the brief Italian occupation), Selassie made great strides in modernizing his nation. New tax programs were implemented and the constitution was revised under his rule.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1972, an enormous drought hit Ethiopia resulting in the deaths of over 200,000 citizens. Local rulers conspired to keep this information from Emperor Selassie, and when the information was finally revealed, the government's credibility with the common citizenry was seriously undermined. Combined with a major economic recession, the chaos within the government due to the drought provided the opportunity for officers within the Ethiopian military to stage a coup and take over the government. Haile Selassie I died on August 27th, 1975 when it is believed that he was suffocated in his sleep while imprisoned by the military government.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 2005 Ethiopia underwent its second multiparty election. Despite claims of corrupted vote counting, much of the international community saw this election as a positive step for Ethiopia's future.

August 1975; vermutlich wurde er wдhrend seiner Inhaftierung durch das Militдrregime im Schlaf erstickt.[PARAGRAPH:1]2005 fanden in Дthiopien die zweiten Wahlen mit mehreren Parteien statt. TEXT.Italian: Molti storici credono che l'Etiopia sia la culla della razza umana. Nella depressione di Afar и infatti stato trovato Lucy, uno scheletro umano di 3,2 milioni di anni fa. Oltre a Lucy ci sono perт poche prove che suggeriscano (o neghino) che l'Etiopia fosse abitata prima dell'ottavo secolo a.C., quando una teoria vuole che si siano insediati dei profughi ebrei provenienti da Egitto, Sudan e Arabia del sud.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il primo governo di cui si ha testimonianza in Etiopia fu il Regno di Axum, nel primo secolo a.C. Le informazioni sono perт scarse: il fondatore del regno rimane sconosciuto. Sotto il governo di Axum l'Etiopia divenne la prima nazione cristiana in Africa. All'incirca nel 330 d.C. Frumentius, un greco di Tiro, venne consacrato quale primo vescovo di Etiopia da Sant'Attanasio. Frumentius diffuse il cristianesimo in Etiopia attraverso la costruzione di chiese sulle terre che gli furono concesse dall'imperatore di Axum. Nonostante il cristianesimo sia diventato molto diffuso solo piщ tardi, Frumentius puт esserne considerato il primo diffusore.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nonostante l'Etiopia sia stata tradizionalmente bersaglio di incursioni musulmane, la prima invasione su larga scala ebbe successo solo nel 1528. Al comando dell'Imam Ahmad ibn Ibrihim al-Ghazi, le forze musulmane spazzarono l'Etiopia, sconfiggendo quelle dell'imperatore e costringendolo alla fuga. Incapace di riconquistare la patria con le sole forse etiopi, l'imperatore Lebna Dengel Dawit II chiese aiuto ai portoghesi per sconfiggere gli invasori. Nel 1541 i portoghesi inviarono un esercito di 400 moschettieri in aiuto dell'imperatore e, anche se tali forze furono sconfitte nella battaglia di Wofla, i musulmani furono costretti a ritirarsi quando il loro capo venne ucciso, l'anno successivo, nella battaglia di Wayna Daga.[PARAGRAPH:1]L'Etiopia fu sconquassata da una serie di conflitti interni durante il sedicesimo e il diciassettesimo secolo. Pur non dividendo la nazione, tali conflitti erosero il potere centrale dell'impero fino a quando le famiglie in lotta vennero sconfitte da Tewodros II, che governт dal 1855 al 1868. Nonostante una prestigiosa carriera militare, Tewodros II commise un terribile passo falso dal punto di vista politico quando, nel 1867, imprigionт diversi cittadini britannici dopo che la regina Vittoria non rispose a una sua lettera. La Gran Bretagna inviт un esercito a salvare i propri cittadini e, alla sconfitta della propria armata, Tewodros II si suicidт.[PARAGRAPH:1]Successivamente, gli italiani, che nel 1870 avevano acquistato una cittа costiera dell'Eritrea da un sultano locale, affermarono che il Trattato di Uccialli (1889), un accordo tra Italia ed Etiopia sui confini ufficiali tra Etiopia ed Eritrea, garantiva loro il dominio sull'intera Etiopia, anche se in realtа specificava solamente una porzione davvero piccola dell'Etiopia settentrionale. Gli italiani inviarono un esercito alla conquista dell'Etiopia, ma furono respinti dall'imperatore Menelik II, nella battaglia di Adua. Dopo la sconfitta gli italiani firmarono il Trattato di Addis Abeba (1896), che riconosceva l'Etiopia come stato indipendente. Gli italiani sarebbero perт tornati.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nel 1936 gli italiani invasero e occuparono ancora l'Etiopia, stavolta sotto la dittatura fascista di Mussolini, costringendo l'imperatore a fuggire in Inghilterra. Gli italiani vennero poi sconfitti nel 1941 dalle forze congiunte inglesi ed etiopi.[PARAGRAPH:1]Forse il piщ influente imperatore dell'era moderna in Etiopia fu Haile Selassie I. Governт dal 1930 fino alla sua morte nel 1974 (con la breve parentesi dell'occupazione italiana), e fece grandi passi avanti nella modernizzazione della propria nazione. Vennero implementati nuovi schemi di tassazione e fu rivista la costituzione.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nel 1972, un'enorme siccitа colpм l'Etiopia causando la morte di oltre 200.000 persone. I governanti locali cospirarono per mantenere segreta quest'informazione all'imperatore Selassie, ma quando si seppe la credibilitа del governo presso i cittadini ne uscм seriamente compromessa. Il caos all'interno del governo causato dalla siccitа, combinato con una grande recessione economica, diede l'opportunitа ad alcuni ufficiali dell'esercito etiope di fare un colpo di stato. Haile Selassie I morм il 27 agosto 1975 quando, si dice, venne soffocato nel sonno mentre era prigioniero del governo militare.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nel 2005 in Etiopia si tenne la seconda elezione multi-partito. Nonostante illazioni riguardanti un falso conteggio dei voti, la comunitа internazionale ha visto in queste elezioni un momento positivo per il futuro del Paese.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Khmer Empire was a kingdom located in Southeast Asia from 790 until 1431 AD. At its height, the Khmer Empire covered fully one half of Southeast Asia, encompassing what is today Cambodia, Laos, Thailand and parts of Myanmar.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Khmer Empire was founded on the remnants of the kingdom of Chenla, which had spread itself across much of Cambodia and Laos, but had become fractured and weakened by the eighth century AD. A former Chenla prince, Jayvaraman II, returned to the area after his education in Java and created the base of power for the Khmer Empire in the region that is today central Cambodia.[PARAGRAPH:2]The fractured state of Southeast Asia after the collapse of Chenla made the unified strength of the Khmer a welcome presence in the region. The new nation quickly annexed many of its smaller neighbors, sometimes peacefully, sometimes less so.[PARAGRAPH:2]As their prominence grew, the Khmer kings initiated many grand public works projects. King Yasovarman I, ruling from 889 to 915, built Yasodharapura, the first major capital of the Khmer, on a site that would remain important throughout Khmer history. Yasovarman also constructed the East Baray, a massive raised reservoir that was capable of holding over 60 million cubic meters of water.[PARAGRAPH:2]Not long after Yasovarman's reign, internal struggles began to sweep the Khmer Empire. And while a number of impressive works of construction were completed during this period, it was not until the reign of Jayavarman V, from 968 to 1001 that the Khmer Empire could again find itself in relative peace. And it would still be another century until Suryavarman II would again make the Khmer a force to be reckoned with.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ascending to the throne in 1113, Suryavarman II established himself as a firm ruler over the squabbling princes that wreaked havoc on the reign of his father, Suryavarman I. Wisely guiding the forces within his nation, Suryavarman the younger would turn the Khmer Empire into the most powerful kingdom in southeast Asia. Extending his domain over much of neighboring Thailand and Myanmar and constructing Angkor Wat, a monumental temple complex erected not far from the site of the original Khmer capital of Yasodharapura, Suryavarman would guide his Empire to its greatest heights.[PARAGRAPH:2]Shortly after the death of Suryavarman in 1150, relations would sour between the Khmer and the Champa Empire, former allies of the Khmer, and would lead to the sacking of Angkor Wat in 1177, nearly drawing to an end the reign of the Khmer kingdom. The kingdom would be given one last flourish under the reign of Jayavarman VII, whose keen military insight brought the Champa under Khmer control. A devout Buddhist, Jayavarman also littered the Cambodian countryside with new temples.[PARAGRAPH:2]Jayavarman's reign would mark the end of the powerful rulers of the Khmer. A Thai uprising established the kingdom of Ayutthaya in 1350, which would eventually absorb all that once was the Khmer Empire within its borders by 1431.

TEXT.Italian: L'Impero Khmer era un regno che si estese nel sudest asiatico dal 790 al 1431 d.C. Al massimo del suo splendore, l'Impero Khmer copriva interamente metа del sudest asiatico, comprendendo quelli che sono gli attuali Cambogia, Laos, Tailandia e parte del Myanmar.[PARAGRAPH:1]L'Impero Khmer fu fondato sui resti del regno di Chanla, che si estendeva su gran parte di Cambogia e Laos ma che, nell'ottavo secolo d.C., si era sgretolato e indebolito. TEXT.English: [TAB]The Babylonian Empire was, rather than a new idea, a reinvigoration of the old Sumerian Empire, which had also occupied what is today Southern Iraq. Babylonia was formed from a collection of roughly a dozen city states and was named for its capital city of Babylon. Originally a disorganized region, Babylon and Babylonia began to grow as a center for culture, trade, and religion under the rule of Hammurabi in 1728BC. Location of one of the seven ancient wonders - the Hanging Gardens - Babylonia became the jewel of the ancient world.[PARAGRAPH:2]Hammurabi was the first known ruler of united Babylonia as well as its greatest lawgiver. Hammurabi's Code of Laws regulated Babylonian life in such a way as to make the consequences of most criminal acts publicly known. Citizens could then structure their behavior based on these laws leading to a more organized society. So comprehensive was the Babylonian Code that little about its laws or governmental system changed in the entirety of its 1,200 years of existence. Babylon was so revered for this system that cities and states as far as the Mediterranean would emulate it for centuries.[PARAGRAPH:2]After the death of Hammurabi (1750 BC), the empire slowly declined in power and influence until it was eventually conquered by the Kassites (around 1600 BC) from what are now the mountains of Iran. The Kassites ruled over Babylonia for 576 years, reinvigorating the empire under their reign. Although Hammurabi ruled over Babylonia as a series of interconnected city states, the Kassites were the first rulers of Babylonia to transform the country into an organized territory. The Kassites created trade routes to countries as far away as Greece, Armenia and Turkey. Trade with these nations brought further wealth and status to Babylonia.[PARAGRAPH:2]Towards the end of the Kassite era of rule, Babylonia once again began to fall into decline, in part due to external political and military pressure. In 627 BC, the last Kassite ruler died, and Babylonia revolted under the command of a new leader, Nabopolassar. Nabopolassar's son, Nebuchadnezzar II, ruled Babylonia and brought about another golden era. During his rule, Babylonia became a military power, invading and taking territory in Egypt and Assyria. Not long afterwards, in 539 BC, Cyrus of Persia invaded Babylonia, conquering it, and forever ending Babylonia's existence as an independent territory.[PARAGRAPH:2]Despite numerous regime changes, education reached exceptional heights among the Babylonians. Technical achievements such as the creation of a base 60, "sexigesimal," system of mathematics, are still used to this day. Sixty seconds per minute, sixty minutes per hour: modern time, is in fact, Babylonian time.[PARAGRAPH:2]Much like the Sumerian Empire from which they were descended, Babylonia was a nation of fanatical record-keepers. Starting with Hammurabi and continuing down until the empire's dissolution at the hands of Cyrus and the great Persian emperors, every financial transaction, every court verdict, every contract, and just about anything that could be written down, was - on clay tablets. With laws pertaining to almost every aspect of daily living, a significant amount of data was recorded, and much of this has been uncovered and excavated during the modern era. Researchers have even found several optical devices, similar to magnifying glasses, which were used to allow record keepers to write in smaller cuneiform, in order to fit more information on each clay tablet.[PARAGRAPH:2]Babylonia played an important role in the development of law throughout the world. The creation of Hammurabi's Code of Laws, and the zeal with which his successors, both blood-related and not, upheld those laws, demonstrated for all of history how successful and wealthy a nation could become by following an organized system of government.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The area which encompasses modern Portugal was originally settled by Celtic tribes around 1000 BC and was then subsequently conquered by the Visigoths and finally the Moors. The Christian Kings of Asturia eventually drove the Moors out of the area; the new nation of Portugal was formed after its separation from Spanish rule.[PARAGRAPH:2]Portugal was one of the first great internationally-based sea empires in the European world. Between 1415 and 1665, Portugal created a series of resting and refueling ports along the eastern and western coasts of Africa in a bid to eventually reach the profitable shores of India. In 1498 they achieved their goals when Vasco da Gama reached Kozhikode (known then as Calicut). Several important battles took place between the Arabs (who had previously monopolized spice trade in the Indian Ocean) and the Portuguese during this era, the most important of them being the victory over the Egyptian-Gujarati fleet off of Diu in 1509. This victory assured the Portuguese maritime superiority in the Indian Ocean and enabled them to capitalize on the rich spice trade routes between India and Europe. However, in 1578 King Sebastian of Portugal was killed at the battle of "Field of the Three Kings" in Morocco (which Portugal had long hoped to conquer), along with the majority of his force, destroying a central part of Portugal's land armies.[PARAGRAPH:2] In 1580 the throne of Portugal was given over to the Habsburg kings of Spain, partially a result of the Portuguese weakness after the demise of its own king. At the same time, Portuguese power in both the east and west was declining due to a lack of skilled sailors available in Portugal. The English and the Dutch had also been amassing large navies, and began expanding their spheres of influence along routes traditionally held solely by the Portuguese. Although the Portuguese wrested national control back from the Spanish in a 1640 revolt, they lost their control in Malacca, Ceylon, Cochin, Hormuz, among many others to the Dutch or other seafaring nations. With their eastern territories diminishing, Brazil, discovered by Pedro Alvares Cabral in 1500, became increasingly important.[PARAGRAPH:2]Gold was discovered in Brazil in 1690, which had previously been exploited mostly for its dyewood, sugar, diamonds, tobacco and slaves. The ensuing gold rush boosted the population of Brazil from 200,000 in 1650 to 1.5 million in 1770. Brazil today remains the largest Portuguese-speaking country in the world.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1808, French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte invaded Portugal, forcing the prince regent, Dom Joгo, to flee to Brazil and set up a new government. In 1821, the royal family moved back to Portugal after reclaiming the country. Dom Joгo stayed behind, and then his son, Dom Pedro I, ruled Brazil until the country broke away from its mother country, declaring independence in 1822. [PARAGRAPH:2]After losing Brazil, Portugal focused on building its African acquisitions in order to compete with their British and French counterparts. However, after World War II, the majority of European nations began abandoning their outlying colonies. India forcibly retook the Portuguese colonies still in their territory. In 1974, a democratic government was established in Portugal. This new government negotiated the release of its African holdings, which were promptly devastated by civil war and vicious in-fighting generated by the Cold War.[PARAGRAPH:2]Today Portugal is ruled from its capital in Lisbon as a democratic republic under the constitution of 1976. It remains an important participant in the European Union as well as one of the major environmental reformers of Europe.

Mкme si ces derniers reprennent le contrфle national aux Espagnols en 1640, ils perdent Malacca, Ceylan, Cochin, Hormuz et bien d'autres au profit des Nйerlandais et autres nations navales. TEXT.English: [H1]Golden Ages[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]During certain periods of time, some civilizations seem to burst with energy and creativity. The civilization's people become increasingly productive; technological advances come easy to the civilization; and its culture is the envy of the world. Italy during the Renaissance is one such example, and Great Britain in the 19th century another. In Civilization IV, such periods are called "golden ages."[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Entering a Golden Age[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wonders:[\BOLD] A civilization can enter a golden age by constructing the [LINK=BUILDING_TAJ_MAHAL]Taj Mahal[\LINK] wonder.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Great People:[\BOLD] A civilization can combine one or more [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great People[\LINK] of different types to start a golden age. The cost of this method escalates: the first golden age costs one great person, the second costs two, the third one cost three, and so on.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Golden Ages[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]During a golden age, your civilization greatly increases its output of production and commerce, meaning faster build times and research rates. (In game terms, every space within your city's radii that provides commerce produces an extra commerce, and every space that provides production now produces an additional one.) [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duration of Golden Ages[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Golden ages last eight turns on Normal Speed. If you achieve another golden age while in the midst of one already, the eight additional turns are tacked onto the end of the present golden age. You may increase the length of your Golden Ages by controlling the [LINK=BUILDING_MAUSOLEUM_OF_MAUSSOLLOS]Mausoleum of Maussollos[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]The End of the Age[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Once the golden age ends, your civilization's commerce and production return to normal levels.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.German: [H1]Goldene Zeitalter[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]In bestimmten Zeitabschnitten ist die Energie und Kreativitдt einiger Zivilisationen besonders groЯ. TEXT.English: [TAB]The Byzantine Empire, centered around the city of Constantinople, was the successor to the Roman Empire. At its height, the Byzantine Empire reached from Persia to Spain, controlling nearly all the territory that felt the lap of the Mediterranean's warm waters. [PARAGRAPH:2]When the Byzantine Empire began and the Roman Empire ceased is a point of much contention. Some historians place the beginning of the Byzantine Empire in 300 AD, when Constantine I moved the capital of the Roman Empire from Rome to a city called Byzantium (later know as Constantinople). Others place the birth of the Byzantine Empire at the end of the reign of Theodosius I, who at his death split the Roman Empire into the Western Empire, ruled from Rome, and the Eastern Empire, ruled from Constantinople. [PARAGRAPH:2]Regardless of historic debate, after the sacking of Rome in 476 AD, the Byzantine Empire was to become the foremost European nation in art, trade and stability - although not necessarily all at once. Taking the throne in 527 AD, Justinian I extended the grip of the Byzantine Empire from Constantinople to the furthest coasts of the Mediterranean Sea. However the Empire would not be able to enjoy the benefits of such territorial expansions for long, as Justinian's successor, Justin II, would begin a trend of placating the various enemies of the Empire - the Sassanid Persians, the Bulgars, and the Arabs, newly organized under Mohammed - with territory in exchange for peace. [PARAGRAPH:2]Territorial losses would continue to weaken the Byzantines until a new lineage of emperors, known as the Macedonian Emperors, arose to invigorate the Empire once again. Basil I founded the Macedonian line in 869. Under the Macedonians, the Byzantine Empire once again began to reach outwards, solidifying its hold on much of the territory neighboring Constantinople. Art flourished in their roughly two centuries of rule, as did the Greek Orthodox Church. [PARAGRAPH:2]The new millennium would be a painful one for Byzantium. Relations between the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church had been deteriorating for many years, and the conflict came to a head with the Great Schism (1054), which finally split the two religions. Militarily, increased assaults by the Seljuk Turks culminated in a resounding defeat for the Empire at the Battle of Manzikert, the Empire losing much of its freshly-gained holdings.[PARAGRAPH:2]But once again, the rise of a powerful new dynasty reversed the Empire's decline. This new dynasty, the Comnenius, sent the call to Western Europe for aid in fighting the Seljuk Turks. Pope Urban II, seeing a chance to reconquer the Holy Lands of Antioch and Jerusalem, as well as halt the squabbling of the European Kings, spread the word for the First Crusade. [PARAGRAPH:2]Through the Crusaders' efforts, the Byzantine Empire regained a portion of its lost territory. But the holy warriors of Western Europe became difficult to control, often threatening to assault the very Empire that had requested their aid. John II and Manuel I, the two most prestigious of the Comnenius emperors, held off the Crusaders and safeguarded the empire from a host of external foes, while ushering in a new era of Byzantine artistic and economic prowess. [PARAGRAPH:2]Manuel I Comnenius was the last great emperor of the Byzantines and the last Comneni. The Angeloi dynasty, successors to the Comneni, proved unable to halt the Empire's slow collapse. In 1204, the knights of the Fourth Crusade, summoned by a disposed Angeloi prince, sacked Constantinople and split the Byzantine Empire into three smaller kingdoms. Nicaea, one of these ex-Byzantine states, recaptured Constantinople years later, but all hopes of reviving the Byzantine Empire would be ended with the capture of the city by the Ottoman leader Mehmed II in 1461.

TEXT.Italian: L'Impero Bizantino, costruito attorno alla cittа di Costantinopoli, succedette all'Impero Romano. [PARAGRAPH:1]La questione su quando sia iniziato l'Impero Bizantino e quando sia finito quello Romano и molto controversa. Alcuni storici pongono l'inizio dell'Impero Bizantino nel 300 d.C., quando Costantino spostт la capitale dell'impero da Roma a una cittа chiamata Bisanzio (piщ tardi conosciuta come Costantinopoli). [PARAGRAPH:1]A prescindere dai dibattiti storici, dopo il sacco di Roma nel 476 d.C., l'Impero Bizantino divenne la nazione piщ importante in Europa per l'arte, il commercio e la stabilitа. [PARAGRAPH:1]Le perdite territoriali avrebbero continuato a indebolire i Bizantini fino a quando una nuova stirpe di imperatori, i Macedoni, sorse a rinvigorire ancora una volta l'impero. Nei circa due secoli in cui regnarono i Macedoni fiorirono l'arte e la Chiesa greca ortodossa. [PARAGRAPH:1]Il nuovo millennio sarebbe stato doloroso per Bisanzio. Le relazioni tra la Chiesa Cattolica Romana e la Chiesa Orientale Ortodossa andavano peggiorando da molti anni, e il conflitto arrivт al culmine con il Grande Scisma (1054), che divise le due religioni. Dal punto di vista militare, si andarono moltiplicando gli assalti da parte dei Turchi selgiuchidi, che culminarono in una cocente sconfitta nella Battaglia di Manzikert, per cui l'impero perse gran parte delle terre da poco conquistate.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ma ancora una volta, l'ascesa di una nuova potente dinastia rovesciт le sorti dell'impero. [PARAGRAPH:1]Manuele I Comneno fu l'ultimo grande imperatore bizantino e l'ultimo dei Comneni. TEXT.English: [TAB]The Holy Roman Empire was created in 800 AD by Charlemagne. Covering much of central Europe from the Netherlands to Hungary, the Empire was both a political powerhouse and a hotbed of political intrigue and military conflict. In some ways "Emperors" in name only, the rulers of the Holy Roman Empire were rarely able to exert real control over any territory that was beyond the reach of their personal armies.[PARAGRAPH:2]Although the Holy Roman Empire was not referred to as such until late in the reign of Otto I (962-973), it came into being as a political entity in 800 AD when Pope Leo III, in an effort to break ties with the weakening Byzantine Empire, crowned Charlemagne the "Emperor of the Romans." A keen military strategist and devout Catholic, Charlemagne managed to keep the empire united until his death in 814, upon which the empire steadily dissolved into separate warring states until reunited under the rule of Otto I. While Otto I managed to reunite the empire, his downfall, and that of many successor emperors, was his fixation on Italy. Although Italy was not formally part of the empire, Otto I repeatedly invaded that country in order to secure holdings for the Germanic empire. However, the majority of his military ventures into Italy were unsuccessful, and Otto I only succeeded in eroding his power base in Germany.[PARAGRAPH:2]Throughout its history, the Holy Roman Empire was the stage for conflicts between its Emperors and the Church. Initially it was only the Pope who could designate the Roman Emperor, however over time - especially during the reign of Otto I - it became instead the Emperor who named the next Pope, providing the throne with enormous religious power. During the reign of the Salian Emperors (1024-1125) this practice again changed. A council of churchmen, known as Cardinals, was formed and given the power to nominate and elect popes. This practice has continued with only minor changes to the present day.[PARAGRAPH:2]Charles VI ruled with perhaps the most pragmatic view of his empire. Voted by the Cardinal Council as Holy Roman Emperor in 1355, Charles immediately gave up all imperial ambitions in Italy and instead focused on consolidating power in the Germanic lands and the eastern half of his empire. Accepting that the German cities and territories were the political and military domains of their local rulers, Charles worked with these local leaders to establish a combined dominance instead of attempting to wrest away their power. Unfortunately, upon Charles' death his son Sigismund fell back into the historical fallacy of attempting to control Italy, and the Empire once again continued its decline into irrelevancy.[PARAGRAPH:2]Despite the internal power struggles wracking the Holy Roman Empire, local rulers banded together in order to face the Napoleonic threat from France. From 1792 to 1802, Austria, Prussia and the other German states combined forces with the hope of defeating the invading French, but to no avail. With little territory left under his control, Emperor Francis II resigned the title of Holy Roman Emperor. The Empire was formally dissolved on the sixth of August, 1806.[PARAGRAPH:2]Over its history, the Holy Roman Empire existed more as an idea than an actual administrative organization. The empire's leaders rarely had actual control over their lands, and constant squabbling between fiefdom holders, as well as the church and state, kept the empire from solidifying any real control over its domain. Its recreation has, however, served as a goal which many would-be conquerors in history have strived to achieve, including Otto von Bismark, King William I, and Adolf Hitler.
